The BCCI officials may have accepted a cap of nine years on tenure, but the three-year cooling off period between every term in office is what they are contesting in the Supreme Court. Puneet Bali, who represented the BCCI officials in the Supreme Court on Wednesday , said continuity is the bone of contention and that the Lodha reforms should be re-modelled to ensure the office-bearers get an extended term. “The three-year cooling off period could be applicable for the post of BCCI president. But those who are the joint-secretary or treasu rer should be given a chance to become secretary ,“ Bali told TOI, explaining BCCI's point of view. BCCI also has an objection to FAQs of the Lodha Committee, which do not permit an office-bearer who has completed nine years in the state to come into the BCCI only after a three-year cooling off period. “If no one from the state unit is allowed to continue after completing nine years, then the BCCI will be left without experienced officials to run the cricket affairs,“ Bali said. A section in the BCCI said these objections are just a mechanism by Amitabh Choudhary and Anirudh Chaudhary to remain in office. Justice (retired) RM Lodha agreed with this view.“You can't tweak the reforms just to suit a few individuals.These reforms aren't supposed to be changed. If the board officials want to make their own cooling off rules, it will revert back to the same old system of monopoly,“ Lodha told TOI. Lodha said that there is no harm in fresh faces being given a chance to run the game in the country . “As I have said earlier, others should be given an opportunity to come into the BCCI. If the officials are allowed to stay on for nine years on the trot, they will treat the board like their own property ,“ he said.

The Bhagalpur chief judicial magistrate issued arrest warrants against three people in connection with the multi-crore Srijan fund transfer scam on Wednesday evening.

The accused were identified as Amit and Priya Kumar, the son and daughter-in-law of Srijan Mahila Sahyog Samiti founder Manorama Devi, and Bhagalpur public grievances redressal officer Rajeev Ranjan Singh.

The NGO is accused of working in cahoots with bankers and treasury officials to illegally divert government funds into its own accounts. The scam, estimated at over Rs 700 crore, first came to light when a government cheque presented to a Bhagalpur bank bounced due to insufficient funds on August 3.

Amit and Priya had taken over the reins of the NGO after the demise of Devi in February. Lookout notices have been issued against the duo to ensure they do not leave the country. Singh used to be a land acquisition officer at Bhagalpur.

Investigators have also found a December 2003 letter from the then Bhagalpur district magistrate, instructing senior district officials to deposit government funds into the NGO’s bank accounts. As many as 10 people have come under the scanner in connection with the alleged scam, which the state opposition has compared with Madhya Pradesh’s Vyapam controversy.

The Rashtriya Janata Dal (RJD) has been on the offensive in the state assembly for over three days now, raising fears that the five-day monsoon session may come a cropper. It has demanded the resignations of chief minister Nitish Kumar and deputy chief minister Sushil Kumar Modi for their alleged involvement in the scam.

RJD chief Lalu Prasad has even alleged foul play in the death of Mahesh Mandal, a welfare department official accused in the fund transfer scam. Mandal had succumbed to chronic kidney disease on August 20.

The Bhagalpur district magistrate had initially appointed a three-member committee led by deputy development commissioner Amit Kumar to investigate the Srijan scam. The probe revealed that certain fraudsters illegally transferred government funds to the NGO’s accounts by forging the district magistrate’s signature. It also found that the scam has now spread to multiple departments beyond the geographical boundaries of Bhagalpur. The state government transferred Amit Kumar as the district magistrate of Lakhisarai on August 18.

Besides diverting government funds, the NGO is accused of avoiding government audits between 2007 and 2014 by fudging bank passbooks while continuing to earn interest on the principal amount.

Eleven FIRs have been filed and 18 people arrested in the scam until now. The state government has recommended a CBI probe into the matter.

The BMC panel that probed the July 25 Ghatkopar building crash has concluded that illegal alterations made by local strongman Sunil Shitap, owner of the ground-floor flats, resulted in the tragedy that claimed 17 lives. Shitap, known for his Shiv Sena links, carried out modifications without taking any precautions for the structure's stability, and over-exposure of RCC columns acted as trigger for the collapse, the report has said. It also mentioned that photos published by TOI on July 28 had made the over-exposure of columns evident. The inquiry committee headed by additional civic commissioner Vijay Singhal has made over a dozen recommendations, all of which have been accepted by the civic chief, and suggested disciplinary action against several civic officials for administrative lapses. The BMC panel that probed the July 25 Ghatkopar building crash has blamed local strongman Sunil Shitap for making illegal alterations that resulted in loss of lives and property . The three-member committee submitted its report to civic chief Ajoy Mehta on Wednesday . One of its recommendations is that illegal structural alterations in buildings be considered a cognizable offence. The committee found that while the building itself was not in great health, it would have survived longer if it had not been tampered with indiscriminately . One of the residents informed the panel that just a day before the crash, he had had a meeting with Shitap at the latter's ground-floor premises and had seen that the concrete cover of six columns had been removed and reinforcements exposed. The activity carried on in the premises on the morning of the collapse was `the last straw which broke the camel's back', the committee has said. The panel also recorded the statement of Dr Padma Khade, who had been running a maternity home from Shitap's ground-floor premises from July 2009 up till a month before the tragedy . Khade said that the last delivery in the maternity home was done on June 25, exactly a month before the crash. She told the committee that she had moved her belongings from the premises on July 4 but Shitap had pressurized her to vacate the place even before that by sending in labourers for carrying out work. The committee observed that it seemed Shitap was in a hurry to get work done faster on his proposed `Shitap' hospital, for which he had made two applications to the Medical Officer, Health (MOH), N ward, in his wife's name. The report, in addition, examined other unauthorized works carried out by Shitap--two in Ghatkopar itself, and then at a lounge at Powai--and noted that the accused “has been acting extremely irresponsibly, showing disregard for rules and regulations and other fellow residents' concerns“. “He seems to be indulging in unauthorized construction in N ward, S ward areas and grabbing public land and constructing structures for monetary benefits,“ stated the report. The deputy municipal commissioner (zone-I) and director have been asked to ensure that all recommendations of the committee are implemented in six months.

The Bombay high court on Wednesday said that it was satisfied with the measures taken by the state government to “maintain law and order“ and declined to issue any directives to prevent attacks by cow vigilantes during Bakri Eid. “We are satisfied that the state has taken necessary steps to ensure peace during festivals,“ said a division bench of Justices Bhushan Gavai and Makrand Karnik, while pointing out that this year the Muslim festival of Bakr Eid coincides with the Hindu festival, Ganesh Chathurthi. The court accepted the state's assurance that no untoward incidents will take place while transporting animals for Eid. The court was hearing a PIL seeking action against “self-proclaimed gau rakshaks“.

The boss of Australia's foreign intelligence agency has been criticised for clenching his fist in a photo with Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte. Mr Duterte used the pose in his 2016 presidential campaign, a symbol of his tough and controversial crime policies. Critics said the photo of Nick Warner, the Australian Secret Intelligence Service (Asis) director-general, sent an inappropriate message from Canberra. The Australian government said the photo was not Mr Warner's idea. Mr Duterte has been condemned by human rights groups for his crackdown on drugs in the Philippines, which has seen thousands of people die at the hands of police. The drug war has sparked civil unrest and protests against Mr Duterte's presidency, as well as criticism from community leaders. Photos of the meeting between Mr Duterte and Mr Warner at Manila's Malacanang Palace were shared on the president's Twitter account. Elaine Pearson, the director of Human Rights Watch in Australia, said Mr Warner's gesture was unwise. "Sickening to see head of Australia's spy agency fist-bumping a man who has instigated the killing of thousands," she wrote online . "You wouldn't pose like this with a mass murderer. And one day, Duterte may be indicted for crimes against humanity." Australian MP Anthony Byrne said the photo was "completely inappropriate for the head of one [of] our most important intelligent services to be in". However Australian Foreign Minister Julie Bishop, whose department oversees Asis, said she was "confident it would not have been his [Mr Warner's] idea". "I do not know the details of how it came about or who released the photograph," she said. "But of course the Australian Secret Intelligence Service is called a secret intelligence service for a reason. Preferably the work that Asis does is below the surface but there are instances where it comes public." Earlier this week, Ms Bishop told Fairfax Media that Australia was deeply concerned about extra-judicial killings in the Philippines. Media outlets reported a palace official as saying Mr Duterte and Mr Warner had discussed routine matters such as regional security. Last week, the Australian government added so-called Islamic State in East Asia to its official list of terrorist organisations. It follows warnings by Australian intelligence chiefs about security threats in South East Asia.

The Cabinet has approved setting up of a panel of ministers to oversee the process of consolidation in state-run banks. Finance minister Arun Jaitley said names for the panel would be decided by PM Narendra Modi. “The objective is to create strong banks,“ Jaitley told a news conference and added that decisions for merger would be “purely commercial“. The FM made it clear that the proposal must start from the boards of banks. The proposals from banks for in-principle approval to formulate schemes of amalgamation shall be placed before the Alternative Mechanism (AM), which is the panel of ministers. He said the Cabinet decision is expected to facilitate creation of competitive banks in the public sector space to meet credit ne eds of a growing econo my , absorb shocks and ha ve the capacity to raise re sources without depending unduly on the state exchequer . Asked whether some mergers were possible this year , the FM said he hoped that some would happen but didn't give numbers. “After in-principle approval, the banks will take steps in accordance with law and Sebi's requirements. The final scheme will be notified by the central government in consultation with the Reserve Bank of India,“ said Jaitley . “Our experience of consolidation has been positive,“ the FM said, adding that an Alternative Mechanism would help facilitate quick decisions. A government source said there would be no job loss as a result of mergers. Bank unions ha ve protested against consolidation moves fearing job loss. Last year , five associate banks of SBI and the Bharatiya Mahila Bank were merged with SBI in record time, unlike earlier mergers of State Bank of Indore and Saurashtra. There are 20 PSBs other than SBI. The banking scenario has changed since 1970s and '80s when banks were nationalised, with increased presence from private sector banks, NBFCs, regional rural banks, payment and small finance banks. Successive governments have been pushing the idea of consolidation to create four-to-five strong banks of global scale but now officials are talking about 10-15 banks in the public sector space.

The cabinet has okayed the setting up of a ministers' panel to oversee the process of consolidation in state -run banks. The FM said the move is expected to help create competitive PSU banks to meet the credit needs of a growing economy .

The Cabinet on Wednesday approved the proposal of the railways ministry to close the Bharat Wagon and Engineering Company -a central public sector enterprise. More than 600 employees of BWEL will benefit from the voluntary retirement scheme to be offered at 2007 pay scale.The government will have to provide one time grant of Rs 151.2 crore towards severance package and for clearing the current liabilities of the company.“This measure will stop flow of financial support from public funds for carrying on the operations of sickloss making BWEL resulting in savings for the government,“ an official statement said.

The calls from Infosys' clients have already begun and sales teams are finding their prospects shying away, adding an increasing urgency to the need to settle the dispute at India's secondlargest IT services company. The trouble at Infosys, which has been brewing since the start of this year, boiled over on Friday when CEO Vishal Sikka resigned and the company's board attacked founder NR Narayana Murthy for causing his exit. Sikka had been spearheading Infosys' change and his sudden departure and the prospect of a long-drawn out battle has spooked its customers. “We've been fielding calls today from concerned current (and potential) clients. ...news will certainly slow down decision-making for prospects that have shortlisted Infosys,“ Stanton Lacy, principal analyst with technology advisory firm ISG, said. Lacy said the calls started coming in as soon as news of Sikka's resignation hit.Even at Infosys, the scale of the impact has begun to hit. “Sales teams can't talk about anything else or sell because this is what comes up,“ an executive with knowledge of the matter said. A second executive said `sales teams have stagnated.' Foreign analysts, who broker deals with clients, say clients remember the last round of management turmoil and a re-run is not encouraging.“If, every four years or so, you have to call clients and tell them you are stable, chances are they are going to start having doubts,“ said a technology analyst, who declined to be identified. The analyst was alluding to the 2013-2014 period when Infosys saw a whole slew of top management exits and founder NR Narayana Murthy returned to steady the company. Infosys did not respond to a request seeking comment for this story. To be sure, other companies have seen senior executives leave in trying circumstances and in those cases the company's board comes to its aid in soothing clients. Infosys does not, currently, have that luxury. “The board is out talking to investors and shareholders. They should be talking to clients. Who is taking care of the business?“ a former senior Infosys executive said.ET had previously reported that Infosys' rivals will be the first in Infosys' rivals will be the first in line to benefit from the turmoil at the company. They have already begun to scent blood. “Existing clients won't walk out immediately but there will be the more than usual quota of questions when they pitch for new clients.The biggest danger is the all this is happening just when digital deals are getting bigger and there is a real threat of losing out there. Infosys stands the risk of losing out a new wave of digital business if matters are not resolved soon,“ a senior executive of a rival company told ET. Infosys has said calling up its customers and calming waters is at the top of its agenda. Sikka outlined the outreach to clients in an investor call on the day his resignation was announced.

The carniva finally hit town yesterday with Conor McGregor and Floyd Mayweather Jr. put ting on a bit of a fashion show before promising to knock each other out in their highly anticipated box ing match. Mayweather wore a fe dora and gold rimmed glass es while McGregor sported a three-piece suit and tie and aviator sunglasses as they made separate appear ances before a crowd of sev eral hundred people in front of the arena where they wil fight Saturday night. The two got into an un planned verbal confronta tion as they moved between the outdoor stage and the arena, though it was brief l Bodyguards kept them apart , and both fighters are smart enough not to do anything to jeopardize their immense paydays from what could be the richest fight ever. “It's work,“ Mayweather said when asked if he was having fun. “My job is to be a fighter.“McGregor, meanwhile, reiterated his vow to knock Mayweather out within two rounds, and claimed the boxer was getting desperate in making comments about his weight and stamina.l “Let him keep praying about weight and fatigue.All he's doing is praying,“ McGregor said. “But he's praying to the new god of boxing.“. The crowd for one of the final promotional events was small and not terribly vocal, especially after waiting an hour or two in 100-degree heat to see the fighters.There was no one in line at T-Mobile Arena's three ticket windows, where plenty of expensive tickets remain for the bout. The big money for the two fighters will come from pay-per-view sales, and early indications are that it could break all records.Some 50 million people may watch in the United States alone, with millions more tuning in worldwide. Estimates vary wildly, but Mayweather could pocket $200 million, while McGregor might make $100 million.
